Award.AwardTitle: 2017 Shipboard Scientific Support Equipment R/V Atlantic Explorer
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal impact of the present proposal is under Merit Review Criterion 2 of the Proposal Guidelines (NSF 13-589). It provides infrastructure support for scientists to use the vessel and its shared-use instrumentation in support of their NSF-funded oceanographic research projects (which individually undergo separate review by the relevant research program of NSF). The acquisition, maintenance and operation of shared-use instrumentation allows NSF-funded researchers from any US university or lab access to working, calibrated instruments for their research, reducing the cost of that research, and expanding the base of potential researchers.

The Program recommends an award of $90,421 for the purchase of the following:

1) Replacement Tender/Workboat $69,954
2) Electronic Chart Upgrade $6,174
3) Navigation Depth Sounder $14,293
$90,421

POR.DRECONTENT:
2017 Shipboard Scientific Support Grant – Outcomes

This grant was originally funded to purchase the following equipment –

Deck Equipment:

1- Replacement of existing 5.0 meter Safeboat tender with new Zodiac Mil-Pro Model 550 SRMN rigid-hulled, foam-collared tender, with a 90 horsepower outboard. This includes modifications and upgrades to the ship’s boat davit and winch davit, outfitting equipment for the boat, and a boat cover.

Navigation Equipment:

2 – Replacement of existing electronic charting software and desktop computer, with new Rosepoint electronic charting software and new computer server.

3 – Replacement of failed Simrad depth sounder with new Furuno FE-800 depth sounder and new hull-mounted transducer.

All items have been purchased and installed aboard the R/V ATLANTIC EXPLORER.

Additional items purchased:

The following additional items were also purchased with this grant, through cost-saving measures that included crew labor, wherever possible, and invoice savings from the equipment vendors during the procurement process:

1 - New Nobeltec electronic charting software, to replace the recently-purchased Rosepoint software. After the purchase and installation of a new computer and the Rosepoint software, it was found that Rosepoint did not live up to its description – it was difficult to use, not particularly user-friendly, and not well-suited for the work environment aboard the vessel. In the meantime, Nobeltec had come out with a new version of its own software, which met our requirements and needs much better, and with much less in yearly maintenance costs than the costs found with Rosepoint. We elected to scrap the Rosepoint system after only 6 months, and switched back to a new, much-improved version of Nobeltec, and have been very satisfied with the results.

2 – The   purchase and installation of a new JRC JLR-21 GPS Compass system. In May, 2018, the vessel’s old Sperry Mk-37 gyro-compass system failed, with parts no longer being available, due to the age of the compass and its components. We were able to purchase and install a new GPS-based compass system, accurate to 0.1 degree, for both vessel navigation and science equipment heading input. This system was requested, approved, purchased, and installed, during a 2-day in-port period when the vessel was in Narragansett, Rhode Island.

3 – Purchase of additional Emergency Escape Breathing Devices (EEBD’s). We were able to purchase additional EEBD’s for the vessel, beyond the original group purchase by NSF, so that instead of only replacing the below-deck units, we were able to replace all EEBD’s aboard the vessel, so that all units are now new, with the same inspection and expiration date.

Furuno FE-800 Depth Sounder purchase (FUNDING SOURCE):

Originally, when the vessel was dry-docked in January, 2017, it was found that the old Simrad home-built depth finder system had failed, and was no longer repairable or serviceable. Because the 2016 SSSE grant would expire within 3 months, and the 2017 proposal had not yet been funded, the NSF Program Manager requested that we revise and re-submit our 2017 SSSE proposal, to include the cost of the new depth sounder.

The purchase was made with Ship Operations funds initially, and then transferred to the SSSE grant in March, 2017. A mistake was made, however, on my part, in that there was approximately $13,000 remaining in the 2016 SSSE grant, after the purchase and installation of the one item funded in that grant – a Furuno DS-60 Doppler Speed Log. When the new depth finder had been purchased and installed, the final invoice was almost exactly the amount left in the 2016 SSSE grant, which is where I transferred the purchase of the depth finder. It was only after the 2016 SSSE grant was closed out that I discovered my mistake, and by then, it was too late to reverse the charge. I notified the NSF Program manager of my mistake, and when the emergency purchase of the new JLR-21 Compass system became necessary, in May, 2018, I requested approval, which was granted by NSF, to use those remaining 2017 SSSE funds to make that purchase, which was also approximately $13,000.
